nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) leads to artifacts that misrepresent long-term energy technology transitions and therefore produces unrealistic carbon price trajectories
IAMs aim to couple economic output, greenhouse gas emissions, climate change (temperature), and climate damages to derive optimal carbon prices for policy

CES was originally developed for capital-labor substitution and is share-preserving: marginal rate of technical substitution depends on factor ratios causing exponentially increasing required input of substitutes when replacing a dominant factor

Applying CES to model the substitution of fossil energy by renewable energy over long periods forces exponentially increasing quantities of renewables to replace fossil shares and yields exponentially increasing carbon prices
Technical energy transitions historically follow S-curve diffusion with dynamically changing elasticity of substitution, not constant elasticity

IAM structure requires representing long-term economic growth, translating that into GHG emissions, mapping emissions to temperature change, and mapping temperature change to economic damages; results are often summarized as a marginal carbon price distinct from the social cost of carbon

Mathematically, CES MRTS and price-relative equations imply that when an input has a large initial share, replacing it requires exponentially larger inputs of the substitute and leads to nonlinearly rising relative prices

A stylized CES example substituting fossil (F) with renewables (R) shows (i) exponential increase in R required, (ii) saturation well before complete substitution, (iii) carbon price small initially then exponential, and (iv) sensitivity to elasticity parameter
When energy demand grows over time, the CES-driven artifacts (quantities and prices) are exacerbated, making high substitution levels even more difficult in the model

Empirical literature documents S-curve diffusion and learning-by-doing for energy technologies, with deployment accelerating as penetration increases and costs falling, inconsistent with CES share-preserving behavior

The CES example demonstrates that the monotonically increasing marginal carbon price commonly produced by IAMs is an artifact of CES application and not necessarily reflective of technical substitutability or plausible substitute costs

Historical energy transition datasets and diffusion models (logistic, Gompertz, Bass) fit observed S-curve patterns and show exponential deployment and cost declines for technologies like wind, solar, batteries

Several mainstream IAMs and hybrid models (GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE and others) use CES or nested CES variants for production and energy sectors and produce exponentially rising carbon price trajectories and limited renewable penetration in scenarios

Policy-relevant implications of CES-induced artifacts include: price diversion (overreliance on carbon price rather than physical deployment planning), sticker shock (political paralysis from extreme projected prices), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent technologies already specified in base shares)

A practical mitigation is to use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to expected technical diffusion or to adopt physics-driven models; dynamic elasticity reproduces S-curve-like transitions and prevents unbounded carbon price growth

Recommendation: IAMs should replace or augment constant-elasticity formulations with dynamic-elasticity or physical energy principles models and incorporate deployment targets and storage/technology learning to produce more realistic mitigation pathways and carbon price estimates
